main event: Walter Giesler observed three bright, unconventional objects in the sky traveling in a westerly direction at a very high rate of speed on October 22, 1957.
interesting points: The objects were completely silent and much brighter than surrounding stars or planets., They appeared to be at a very high altitude, possibly 30,000 to 40,000 feet., The objects made a sudden turn towards the south and disappeared almost immediately., After the sighting, Giesler notified the police, who had received similar reports from others in the area., The characteristics observed could not be comparable to any known aircraft.
sighted object: three bright, unconventional objects in the sky
witness description: Walter Giesler, who was driving home from work at the time of the sighting
